node.title: How to find out which elements the node (dof) is on
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
hi,
I need to do different things to solutions of different elements, but in continuous finite element method, different elements will share some degrees of freedom (dof), which will result in some solutions being manipulated multiple times. I need to know which elements each Node or dof belongs to, and then do special handling as appropriate. So how can I get these messages when the pointer to the Node or dof is known?
Thank you very much for your attention and I would quite appreciate it if you have any suggestion!

Hello
A loop on nodes instead of elements will prevent this double modification, at least for lagrange variables.
Nodes inherit from the DofInterface, you can get the dof of each variable using the dof_number(variable, system) routine.
Alternatively, you can work with the DoFMap directly
Guillaume

Thank you for your reply. Now I do want to handle it that way, but I need to know which element each Node is on before I can do the corresponding calculation operation. The coefficients in the calculation depend on which element it is on.
there is a node_to_elem_map you can get from the mesh to help with that
This seems to be exactly what I need, thank you so much for your help!

@hityyds please mark this as answered if this answered your question. I will note that we do not assign a node an element owner. As you know several elements can share a given node; we do not pick any of them as the node "owner"

@lindsayad I apologize, I thought I had already marked it as answered. Thank you for the reminder. Regarding whether a node has an element owner, I'm curious how moose assigns material data to nodes at the interfaces of different materials.

The traditional moose material system has no support for nodal material property evaluation. The on-the-fly functor system does allow nodal evaluations, but it requires the user to specify a subdomain ID. This is to eliminate ambiguity about how to evaluate potentially discontinuous properties at subdomain interfaces
Thanks for your detailed explanation!

node.title: Format of PETSc syntax for use in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Given the following PETSc syntax:
-da_refine 5 -snes_monitor -ksp_monitor -snes_view -pc_type mg
How would I form the above syntax in MOOSE using "  petsc_options_iname =, and
petsc_options_value = " ?

Hello
Any option that goes in pairs gets split between those two parameters (for example -pc_type lu)
Any option that stands alone (for example -ksp_view_pmat or -snes_monitor) goes in the 'petsc_options=' parameter
Or you can drop everything on the command line
Guillaume

We do not use PETSc DMDA (or DMPlex), so -da_refine will not do anything (you should see it show up in the options left table). Additionally we do not have support for coarsening for our DM implementation, so -pc_type mg will not get you anywhere. For instance if you pass -pc_type mg -pc_mg_levels 2 to a MOOSE simulation, you will get this error
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.082207e+00
[0]PETSC ERROR: --------------------- Error Message --------------------------------------------------------------
[0]PETSC ERROR: No support for this operation for this object type
[0]PETSC ERROR: No method coarsen for DM of type libmesh
The most we've done in our finite element stack with respect to geometric multigrid is libMesh/libmesh#2047

node.title: How to make a subclass that can take a modified FEProblemSolve::solve() into it?

node.bodyText:
Hello
You can either make a new problem class and specify in the s problem block to use it
Or you can wait a month or so and we will introduce customized convergence objects. These will let you do what you want. The decision on whether something is converged or not will no longer belong to the problem but to a convergence system, of which you will be able to make custom classes
Guillaume

wow customized convergence objects sounds awesome to me! I can live with this for now.
Thank you @GiudGiud!
Kind regards,
Trai

This line in Transient.C sets up _fixed_point_solve->setInnerSolve(_feproblem_solve);. You can build an object with your modified FEProblemSolve in you TransientMod and set it as the inner object of the existing _fixed_point_solve.

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hello,
I am trying to compile and build Griffin from source for development. I have followed the instructions provided at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/ncrc/applications/ncrc_develop_griffin.html, with one addition. git submodule update --init was skipping the griffin_data submodule, so in addition to git submodule update --init, I also ran git submodule update --checkout, which appears to have successfully downloaded the data. I am working on the INL HPC.
However, I am failing 15 tests. They seem to fall into one of three categories. Below, I have provided the names of the tests that have failed for each identical error message, and below that, I have included one of the failed tests' outputs. node.title: crank-nicolson fails to converge at the initial step
node.bodyText: if I use crank nicolson, it fails to converge in the first timestep. What can be evaluated in-general to address this issue? without specifying any scheme, the simulation runs fine.  I can share the input file here if that helps (but input file is for CRANE - a MOOSE based).

Hello
Which equation are you trying to solve?
Is CRANE open-source?
You can try the troubleshooting steps here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
Guillaume

Trying to solve "ChemicalReactions" network. Yes, CRANE is open source built on MOOSE framework.
If I disable "crank-nicolson", the solver runs fine.

What about bdf2?
Do all the nonlinear equations involved have a time derivative term? That s a known issue for our implementation of crank Nicholson

Yes, all the equations have a time derivative term.
I just tried with bdf2, and it works fine and runs very fast also.
But the physical end time at which I get steady state convergence changes, and the final solution (density of each species) varies slightly with or without bdf2. Is that fine? what is the default time-integrator if I don't specify any? is there a recommended time-integrator for chemical reaction network?

The default time integrator is implicit (first order) Euler.
Some differences in the results is expected if you have not converged the time step size.
I don't know about recommendations for time integration of chemical reaction network. The selection of a numerical scheme is typically done based on what is done elsewhere in the litterature of that field.

Thanks! I will look into the literature.
I guess the fast run I observed now is due to disabling the growth factor in the TimeStepper. Here is the executioner block I use now.
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 1e3#s 
  #solve_type = 'newton'
  solve_type = 'pjfnk'
  #scheme = crank-nicolson
  scheme = bdf2
  petsc_options_iname = '-snes_linesearch_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'basic'  
  automatic_scaling = true
  steady_state_detection = true
  compute_scaling_once = false
  #nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1e-3   
    growth_factor = 1.01    
  []

[]

The growth factor helps the time stepper increase the time step. This can be useful when simply searching for steady state conditions.
Of course for a transient one does not want to grow the time step too much, as it results in a loss of accuracy

Yes, if I disable growth_factor, the simulation is faster and achieve steady state condition quick, but with lose of accuracy. So, I have set it to 1.01. I think the default is 2.
So, I guess I can proceed with bdf2 instead of CN?

You might want to look at this CFD thread regarding BDF2 vs. Crank-Nicolson. I will quote one comment here:


It [BDF2] is, to the best of my knowledge, the only second order implicit A-stable scheme

another quote from that thread

As a practitioner, the very point is that BDF2 is more stable than CN and discretizes the time derivative at n+1.

I was trying to use lstabledirk4 (MOOSE object link), but I get the following error message. And what does the dirk in the below error message refer to? 4th order?
Invalid option "lstabledirk4" in MooseEnum.  Valid options (not case-sensitive) are "implicit-euler explicit-euler crank-nicolson bdf2 explicit-midpoint dirk explicit-tvd-rk-2 newmark-beta".

the shorthand syntax does not support it
add a [TimeIntegrator] sub-block to the Executioner blokc

Thanks! It fixed.
Also, whether MOOSE allows high-order (order > 5th) adaptive dt integration?
5th order has not been implemented but I dont see why we could not implement it if needed

node.title: Jacobian calculation with respect to two variables
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I am developing an action for cohesive zone in poroelastodynamic media, I have a question regarding the jacobian calculation for the traction jump. If the traction jump is function of displacement jump only and if, i am understanding correctly, we use computeQpJacobian to calculate the diagonal entries of the jacobian matrix and computeQpOffDiagJacobian to calculate the Off-diagonal entries of the jacobian matrix.



But, if the traction jump is function of both displacement jump and fluid velocity jump (another variable), the jacobian matrix will be as  follows:

My question is how to implement this new jacobian matrix in moose?
Thank you.

You still use the computeQpOffDiagJacobian method. You just write different Jacobian statements depending on the passed in jvar. Alternatively you can use automatic differentiation and not worry about writing the Jacobians

node.title: Time variable in ParsedFunction not working
node.bodyText:
Hello.
I am trying to change an aux variable with respect to the simulation time using a custom function defined by ParsedFunction.
Following is the snippet of my code.
[AuxVariables]
  [bnds]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
  [c]
    [InitialCondition]
      type = FunctionIC
      function = time
    []
  []
[]
[Functions]
  [time]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 't'
  []
[]

but I do not see variable 'c' changing with time.
Following is the output (.csv).
time | c | gr1area
-- | -- | --
1 | 0 | 654375.0005
2 | 0 | 654375.001
3 | 0 | 654375.0014
4 | 0 | 654375.0019
.
.
.

95 | 0 | 654375.0456
96 | 0 | 654375.0461
97 | 0 | 654375.0466
98 | 0 | 654375.0471
99 | 0 | 654375.0475
100 | 0 | 654375.048

Best Regards,
Ashish

Hello
Initial conditions are evaluated only right before the very first  time step
use an auxiliary kernel (AuxKernel) instead for this

Hello Guillaume,
Thank you very much. Now it is working as expected.
Best Regards
Ashish

node.title: Create node set from post adaptivity mesh failure
node.bodyText:
Dear moose user,
I had a problem on making node set from the post-adaptivity mesh using the following Mesh and Adaptivity block
I got the noncrack node set only the the original gen mesh, not the one from post adaptivity, see the fig below when loading in y-direction condition
Would anyone know how to fix this problem, thx.
Best regards,
Lifeng

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 20
    ny = 10
    xmax = 0.1
    ymax = 0.05
  []
  [./noncrack]
    type = BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator
    new_boundary = noncrack
    bottom_left = '0.05 0 0'
    top_right = '0.1 0 0'
    input = gen
  [../]
[]

[Adaptivity]
  marker = marker
  initial_marker = marker
  initial_steps = 2
  stop_time = 0
  max_h_level = 5
  [Markers]
    [marker]
      type = OrientedBoxMarker
      center = '0.07 0 0'
      length = 0.055
      width = 0.02
      height = 0.1
      length_direction = '1 0 0'
      width_direction = '0 1 0'
      inside = REFINE
      outside = DO_NOTHING
    []
  []
[]

Hello
The ordering of execution does not work to create the nodeset like this.
The mesh is generated by gen and noncrack, then adaptivity is run.
You could:

save the mesh using the checkpoint system (.cpr files), reload it with a FileMeshGenerator, then run the noncrack generator again
OR
try to create a new sideset-updater user object that looks like BoundingBoxNodesetGenerator
An example here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/SidesetAroundSubdomainUpdater.html
of the user-object version of the SidesetAroundSubdomainGenerator

Guillaume

node.title: Extracting data from exoudsiie
node.bodyText:
Hi experts,
I'm not entirely sure if this is the appropriate platform for my query, but I could really use some guidance.
I'm currently running numerous small simulations, each of which generates an exodus file. My goal is to extract a specific variable (cell data) but only from a particular block within these files.
I've been attempting to achieve this using meshio in Python, but I've encountered difficulties in correlating the blocks with my data. It seems that I cannot access the blocks when I open the file with meshio.
Could someone please suggest an approach for dealing with this data extraction issue?
Thanks in advance!

Hello
I think you can work with the vtk python package to do this. But I have never done it.
Alternatively, Paraview has programmable filters that may be friendlier than python packages
Guillaume

The best approach is to build the SEACAS project (documentation), which is the project that "owns" Exodus (SEACAS might already be built by MOOSE?) and use one of the following approaches:

exodus.py (documentation)
exo2mat / mat2exo (documentation)
exotxt / txtexo (documentation)

We do package the SEACAS tools for our users. To install in your MOOSE conda environment, simply:
conda install moose-seacas

Hi all,
thanks for the great ideas. I exported the results as VTK and used meshio to read the files. That worked, thanks!!

node.title: Issue about using MPI for Multiapp
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi all,
I am doing the [TensorMechanics] (old version) and two-phase flow module (like THM) coupling through Multiapp. And the TensorMechanics is the main app in my case.
When I use ./app_name -i case_name_main.i to run my case, it will cost 1693 seconds. However, if I use mpiexec -n 5  ./app_name -i case_name_main.i,  it will cost 5478 seconds. Further, if I use mpiexec -n 10  ./app_name -i case_name_main.i, it will cost 18124 seconds.
Why does using more computing core not cause a decrease in computation time, but result in more computation time? Shouldn't parallel computing improve computational efficiency?
Thanks!

Hello
The solvers do not scale to small numbers of DoFs. Using too many processes can slow down the code
You can try to identify whether tensormechanics or THM is being slow with higher number of cores. Then you can limit the number of processes of the multiapp using the max_procs_per_app parameter
